The Fe-based catalysts are extensively employed for CO2 conversion into lower olefins, fuels and value-added chemicals. Addition of promoters is an efficient strategy to improve activity and manipulate product distribution. Herein, the effect of Ru-Na dual promoters on Fe-based catalysts were systematically investigated. Optimal Ru/Na ratios were found to substantially enhance CO₂ conversion efficiency, while reducing CO selectivity and suppressing lower alkanes formation. Multiple characterizations (TPD, XRD, XPS) were applied to illustrate the influence of the promoters on physiochemical properties of catalysts. Further in situ FTIR and Raman experiments, combined with FTS performance evaluation, revealed the synergistic and balanced effect between the two promoters. This work establishes a general design principle for achieving promoted performance by manipulating surface intermediates concentration, offering valuable guidance for developing advanced CO₂ hydrogenation catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Fe-based catalyst Ru-Na dual promoters Synergistic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Climate change has emerged as a critical global challenge, predominantly driven by industrial CO2 emissions [1,2]. Addressing this challenge necessitates sustainable development and carbon management through capture, storage, and utilization [3,4]. CO2 utilization technology is particularly noteworthy, as CO2 serves as a strategic C1 building block for producing renewable fuels and value-added chemicals due to its intrinsic advantages of abundance, low cost and non-toxicity [5–9]. CO2 hydrogenation to hydrocarbons, such as olefins and liquid fuels, is considered as a modified Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) process. It represents a promising route for CO2 conversion to value-added chemicals. Given the inherent thermodynamic stability of linear CO2 molecules, the development of precisely engineered catalytic systems becomes essential for efficient CO2 conversion [10–12]. Iron (Fe) based catalysts are extensively investigated in CO2 hydrogenation, involving both active species for the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction and FTS [13,14]. Nevertheless, the addition of promoters is required to improve the catalytic performance for Fe-based catalysts. Alkali metals, such as potassium and sodium, have been proven to be efficient promoters for FTS and modified FTS process [15,16], which remarkably facilitate CO dissociation, chain-growth while simultaneously suppressing CH4 production and secondary hydrogenation of olefins. However, their promotional effects are usually accompanied by enhanced carbon deposition [17–19]. Ruthenium (Ru) is a promising catalyst candidate for low temperature FTS, and it has also been used as a promoter to FTS due to its great hydrogenation capability [20–24]. Current research efforts on Ru as promoter mainly focused on cobalt (Co) based catalysts, while relatively few investigations with controversial results were reported on Fe-based catalysts [21–23]. Lee et al. reported that Ru incorporation in Fe-catalyzed CO2 hydrogenation improved CO2 conversion and C–C coupling, thereby increasing the yield of heavy hydrocarbons [24]. Meffre et al. found that increasing Ru content in Ru-Fe bimetallic nanoparticles could efficiently improve the FTS activity [25]. Jiang et al. demonstrated that Fe-K/Al2O3 with Ru modification slightly increased methane selectivity and CO2 conversion, but reduced the selectivity of olefins and higher hydrocarbon products [26]. These conflicting observations highlight the complexity of Ru promotion effects in Fe-based systems. In this work, a series of Fe-based catalysts with Ru–Na dual promoters were prepared and systematically compared with unpromoted Fe and single-promoter analogues. The influence of dual promoters particularly Ru was discussed through multiple characterizations, including X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Complementary in situ FTIR and Raman experiments, combined with FTS performance evaluation, revealed the synergistic and balanced effect between the two promoters. This work deepens the mechanistic understanding of promoter effects on CO2 hydrogenation and provides guidelines for rational design of modified FTS catalysts. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Chemicals Iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 98.5 %) was supplied by Meryer (Shanghai) Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Ammonium carbonate ((NH4)2CO3, 98.5 %) was purchased from Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, 99.8 %) was obtained from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Ruthenium (III) chloride (RuCl3, 99.95 %) was bought from Tianjin Heowns Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Fe2O3 was synthesized via a precipitation method using (NH4)2CO3 as the precipitant. First, 9.70 g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was dissolved in 120 mL deionized water to form a clear orange-yellow solution. 3.46 g of (NH4)2CO3 was dissolved in 36 mL deionized water to form a colorless transparent solution. The (NH4)2CO3 solution was added dropwise to the Fe(NO3)3·9H2O solution and the mixture was continuously stirred for 4 h to form a reddish-brown suspension. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed thoroughly, and dried. Subsequently, the dried material was ground and calcinated in a muffle furnace at 350 °C in air for 4 h to completely remove the excess (NH4)2CO3. The final product, without addition of promoter, is denoted as Fe2O3. Subsequently, the Fe2O3 catalysts were impregnated with 1 wt% Na and varying amount of Ru using sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) and ruthenium chloride (RuCl3) as precursors. The catalysts were dried overnight at 100 °C and then calcined in a muffle furnace in air for 4 h. The resulting catalysts were denoted as Fe-RuxNay, where x and y represent the weight percentage of Ru and Na (wt%), respectively. In order to investigate the effect of Ru on the performance of CO2 hydrogenation and the synergistic effect of Ru-Na, a series of catalysts with fixed Na content and different Ru content, as well as catalysts modified solely by Ru and Na, were synthesized. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns were acquired using a SmartLab powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) operating at 60 kV and 220 mA. The samples were scanned at a rate of 8o/min within the 2θ range of 10o–80o. The relative contents of the different phases were calculated by reference intensity ratios (RIR). Specifically, the intensity of the most intense peak of each phase was obtained from fitting and deconvolution of the XRD patterns. The mass fraction of x phase (wx ) was calculated using the equation (1) (1) w X = I x R I R x ∑ i = 1 N I i R I R i where I is the integrated intensity of the most intense peak and the RIR values are available from the PDF cards. An inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Thermo iCAP 7400) was used to analyze the elemental content of Fe and Ru in the samples. Prior to measurements, the samples were completely dissolved in HNO3 with microwave-assisted digestion using an Anton paar multiwave 5000. The morphology of the samples was characterized by a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) JEM-F200 operated at 200 kV. The particle size distribution was determined by measuring more than 200 nanoparticles randomly selected from different regions. Elemental distribution was assessed using energy-dispersive X-ray mapping (EDX mapping) analysis in the bright field mode. H2-TPR experiments were conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 50 mg of fresh catalyst was pretreated in an Ar flow at 200 °C for 1 h. The gas was then switched to a mixture of H2 and Ar (10 % H2/90 % Ar), and the temperature was elevated from 50 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, during which the TCD signal was continuously recorded. XPS measurements were conducted using a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi XPS instrument equipped with an Al Kα excitation source. The samples were tested under an ultra-high vacuum of 5 × 10−8 Pa. The binding energy was calibrated by referencing the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. Prior to analysis, the catalysts were subjected to in situ reduction in pure H2 at 350 °C for 2 h. The samples were then purged with He for 1 h to eliminate any residual H2. After cooling down to room temperature, a 10 % CO2/He gas mixture was introduced, and the temperature was increased from 50 °C to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. The desorbed species were monitored by using a mass spectrometer (MS) throughout this process. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 3+ instrument. In H2-TPR, the samples (100 mg) were heated from 30 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under 30 mL/min of flowing 10 % H2/Ar. In situ FTIR spectra were collected on an infrared spectrometer (Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50) equipped with an MCT/A detector and a reaction chamber (Harrick Scientific Products Inc.). Prior to analysis, the catalyst samples were pre-reduced at 350 °C under a H2 flow for 2 h in a tubular furnace to ensure complete reduction of the sample to metallic iron. The samples were then transferred into the FTIR in situ cell and heated to 340 °C in an Ar atmosphere. Following collection of the background spectrum, the samples were exposed to a CO/H2 (1:2) flow under atmospheric pressure. The spectra were continuously collected in the range of 4000–650 cm-1 by averaging 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm-1. In situ Raman spectra were collected using a Horiba LabRAM HR confocal Raman spectrometer equipped with a 532 nm visible laser. The laser power applied to the catalysts was approximately 1.2 mW, with a spot size of about 1 μm with a 50 × objective. The exposure time was set to 25 s for each measurement. 2.4 Catalyst tests The catalysts were evaluated in a fixed bed reactor. For a standard test, 200 mg of catalyst was loaded into the tubular reactor. After in situ reduction under a H2 flow (30 mL/min) at 350 °C and 0.1 MPa for 5 h, the catalysts bed was cooled to 340 °C and the pressure was adjusted to 2.0 MPa by introducing Ar into the reactor. The reaction was carried out at a gas hourly space velocity (9000 mL·g−1·h−1), with a gas composition of 67.5 % H2, 22.5 % CO2, 10 % Ar. For CO hydrogenation, the same reactor setup, reduction and cooling procedures were employed as described above, but using 100 mg of catalyst. The reaction was conducted at a GHSV of 40,500 mL·g⁻¹·h⁻¹ with a feed gas composition of 64 % H₂, 32 % CO, and 4 % Ar. To analyze the gaseous products of COx hydrogenation, an online gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B) was applied. An UltiMetal column with a thermal conductive detector (TCD) was employed to analyze the permanent gaseous products by using Ar as an internal standard. For the analysis of C1–C6 hydrocarbons, an HP-AL/S column coupled with a flame ionization detector (FID) were employed. The following equation was employed to calculate the CO2 conversion, CO selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation: CO2 conv. = (FCO2,in -FCO2,out) / FCO2,in. CO sel. = nCO,out/ (nCO2,in -nCO2,out). For CO hydrogenation, CO conversion and CO2 selectivity was determined as follows: CO conv. = (FCO,in -FCO,out) / FCO,in. CO2 sel. = nCO2,out/ (nCO,in -nCO,out). The selectivity of hydrocarbons was calculated based on C fraction by excluding CO2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and reducibility of the as-prepared catalysts The crystal structure of the fresh catalysts was characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. S1, the XRD patterns of all samples displayed characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to the α-Fe2O3 phase (JCPDS 33-0664), with no detectable diffraction peaks of other Fe phases. This suggests that Fe mainly existed in the form of Fe2O3, while Na and Ru promoters were highly dispersed in the catalyst matrix. The morphology was presented in Fig. 1 a, taking the Fe-Ru0.2Na1 sample as an example. The catalyst revealed uniform nanospheres with an average diameter of ∼ 105 nm. EDS mapping analysis (Fig. 1b-e) further demonstrated the homogeneous distribution of Ru and Na promoter elements throughout the catalyst, which is consistent with the XRD results. The elemental composition of promoters was determined by ICP-OES. As listed in Table S1, the measured contents of Na and Ru were in good agreement with their nominal values. To further investigate the effect of Ru and Na on reduction behavior, comprehensive characterization was performed. H2-TPR analysis of the fresh catalysts as well as the XRD and XPS analysis of the reduced catalysts were conducted to illustrate the reducibility and electronic properties of the catalytic systems. Fig. 2 a shows the XRD patterns of all reduced catalysts. All samples exhibited characteristic diffractions corresponding to metallic Fe (JCPDS 06-0696) without any other peaks from iron oxides (Fe2O3, FeO, Fe3O4). The result confirmed that complete reduction to the metallic Fe phase was achieved under the applied reduction conditions. H2-TPR analysis was carried out on the as-prepared catalysts to explore the impact of the two promoters on the reduction capability of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2b, the unmodified Fe2O3 catalyst displayed three H2 consumption peaks at 330 °C, 550 °C, and 605 °C, which could be attributed to the sequential reduction steps of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, Fe3O4 to FeO and FeO to Fe [27–29], respectively. The introduction of Na significantly altered the reduction behavior. The Fe-Na1 catalyst exhibited three reduction peaks at approximately at 380 °C, 600 °C, and 800 °C, representing a substantial shift to higher temperatures compared with the unpromoted Fe2O3 sample. This observation can be attributed to the electronic promotion effect, which created an electron-enriched environment around Fe species, thereby stabilizing the Fe oxides and inhibiting their reduction [30]. In contrast, Ru modification demonstrated a pronounced promoting effect on catalyst reducibility, evidenced by a shift toward lower temperatures of H2-TPR on the Fe-Ru0.2 sample. For the samples with Ru-Na dual additives, the first peak appeared at significantly lower temperature (210-260 °C) compared with both Fe2O3 and Fe-Na1 sample. Considering the low Ru loading and the typical reduction temperature of RuO2 (∼170 °C) [31,32], we proposed that the reduction peaks were primarily attributed to the reduction of Fe species. Although increasing the Ru content further lowered this reduction temperature, the effect was less pronounced than the initial Ru addition. For the Fe3O4-FeO reduction, the reduction temperature (∼600 °C) remained relatively unaffected by Ru modification compared with Fe–Na1. However, the final reduction step (FeO to Fe) showed a significant temperature decrease (∼100 °C) upon Ru addition, though higher Ru content did not provide additional benefits. These results demonstrate that Ru effectively enhances the reducibility of Fe-Na catalysts, particularly facilitating the initial and final reduction steps. The optimal ruthenium content appears to be achieved at relatively low loading, as higher concentrations do not substantially improve the reduction properties. XPS analysis was performed to investigate the electronic interactions between Fe and promoters, which reflect changes in electron density around surface metal species. The Fe 2p spectra of all catalysts represented doublets at approximately 711 eV and 725 eV (Fig. 2c), assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of the Fe phase, respectively [33]. Comparative analysis of the Fe 2p3/2 binding energy revealed distinct electronic effects induced by the promoters. The introduction of Ru resulted in an increase in binding energy of Fe 2p, while Na modification caused a downward shift. These observations can be rationalized by considering the electronegativity values (Pauling scale) of the elements involved: Na < Fe < Ru [34]. Therefore, Na acts as an electron donor to Fe, while Ru mainly functions as an electron acceptor [35,36]. The electronic interactions were further confirmed by examining the Ru 3d spectra (Fig. 2d). After introducing Na as a co-promoter, the Ru 3d peak shifted from 281.2 eV to 281.0 eV, indicative of the electron-donation effect from Na to Ru. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation was systematically evaluated with all catalysts under steady-state operation after approximately 12 h. The comparative activity and selectivity data at this stable stage are presented in Fig. 3 and Table 1 . The pristine Fe2O3 sample exhibited the lowest CO2 conversion among all tested catalysts. When Ru was introduced into the Fe2O3 catalyst, distinct enhancements in CH4 selectivity and lower carbon alkanes production were observed, accompanied by a suppression of C5+ hydrocarbons formation. These results collectively demonstrated that the Ru modification substantially enhances the hydrogenation capability of the Fe-based catalyst. In comparison, Na as a sole promoter exhibited markedly different effects, showing a remarkable improvement in CO2 conversion. This modification simultaneously elevated the olefin-to-paraffin ratio and induced a shift of hydrocarbon distribution to long-chain products. The electron donation of Na provided an electron-rich local environment of Fe species, promoting the activation and dissociation of CO [17]. At the same time, Na promoter could reduce the H/C ratio on the catalyst surface since CO dissociation was greatly enhanced [17,37,38]. C–C coupling and olefin formation were therefore enhanced. Inhibition of olefin reabsorption suppressed secondary hydrogenation, further boosted the olefin selectivity [39]. The abovementioned factors together contributed to the elevated olefin selectivity. The co-modification strategy combining Ru and Na additives demonstrated a synergistic effect on catalytic performance. Compared to Fe-Na1 catalyst, Fe-Ru0.2Na1 sample further increased the CO2 conversion from 42 % to 47 %, along with a reduction in CO selectivity. With the further increase of Ru content, CO2 conversion showed a decreasing trend, and CO selectivity continued to decline. In terms of hydrocarbon products selectivity, when Ru content was low (≤0.4 %), the product selectivity was basically the same as that of Fe-Na1 sample. However, as the Ru content reached 0.6 %, the selectivity of C5+ products decreased significantly, and the products shifted to low-carbon alkane and methane, indicating that the hydrogenation capacity of the catalyst was significantly improved. At the same time, the CO2 conversion is significantly reduced, and the CO selectivity is also reduced to 3.4 %. Generally speaking, the decrease of CO2 reactivity is caused by the low Fischer–Tropsch activity in this tandem reaction system. The CO generated by the RWGS reaction in the first step cannot be consumed in time, resulting in high CO selectivity, which is inconsistent with the trend of CO selectivity change in Fe-Ru0.6Na1 samples. According to literature, Ru is also considered as a CO/CO2 methanation catalyst [40,41]. We speculated that the excessive addition of Ru may form a methanation active center, thus consuming a part of CO in the reaction system, and finally showing low CO selectivity and low activity, with large amount of methane generation. The product distribution of long-chain hydrocarbons in liquid were collected by the cold trap and analyzed using an off-line GC, except for Fe–Ru0.2 and Fe–Ru0.6Na1, due to the low C5+ yields over these two samples. As shown in Fig. S2, the hydrocarbon products shifted to higher carbon number with the introduction of Ru promoter, unveiling an enhanced C–C coupling capacity. This might result from abundant CHx monomers on catalyst surface [42]. Combined with the data in Table 1 and Fig. S2, we concluded that Fe–Ru0.2Na1 catalyst outperform Fe–Na1 on C–C coupling, resulting in a shift of liquid products distribution to longer-chain hydrocarbons. 3.3 Structure and properties of the spent catalysts To elucidate the role of Ru–Na dual promoters in the CO2 hydrogenation process, the spent catalysts were characterized by XRD, as shown in Fig. 4 a and Fig. S3. The XRD patterns showed that the spent Fe–Na1, Fe–Ru0.2Na1 and Fe–Ru0.4Na1 catalysts mainly consisted of Fe5C2 and Fe3O4 phases. In former studies of modified FTS, Fe3O4 was considered the active site for RWGS reaction while the Fe5C2 regarded as an efficient FTS catalyst. During the reaction, the oxidation of carbide species and carburization of oxide species took place simultaneously, and the key point to achieve satisfying catalytic performance was the precisely engineering between these two components [43]. However, as the Ru content was further increased to 0.6 %, a significant phase transformation was observed, evidenced by the appearance of an intense diffraction peak at 44.7o. This peak was attributed to metallic Fe (JCPDS 06-0696), indicating that a large amount of Fe remained in the Fe-Ru0.6Na1 sample after the reaction. To further distinguish the phase composition of the spent Fe–RuxNa1 sample, the XRD measurements were conducted at a low-scan speed (Fig. 4b). With the increase of Ru content, the diffraction peak intensity of Fe5C2 gradually decreased. At a Ru content of 0.6 %, the primary phases shifted to metallic Fe and Fe3C, as evidenced by the main peak at 45.0o (Fe3C) and 44.7o (Fe). The formation of this new Fe3C phase (JCPDS 35-0772), an iron carbide with lower carbon content, was demonstrated to exhibit lower FTS activity than Fe5C2 [44,45], which would contribute to the diminished FTS performance of the Fe–Ru0.6Na1 catalyst. In contrast, an appropriate content of Ru did not alter the phase composition of iron carbides, only with a slight decline in characteristic diffractions intensity in XRD patterns. In other words, excess Ru addition inhibited the formation of active iron carbides. In a typical FTS process, C* species are generated through CO dissociation on the catalyst surface, transforming metallic Fe into Fe carbides that function as efficient active phases [43]. Given Ru promoter enhances the hydrogenation activation capacity of the catalysts, it is suspected that C* species were removed timely by excess H* species. This process inhibited the formation of active Fe carbides, thereby negatively impacting the FTS performance and leading to a reduction in CO2 conversion. We conducted TG analysis on the spent Fe-RuxNa1 catalysts to evaluate their carbon content and phase composition. As illustrated in Fig. 5 a, all catalysts showed a mass gain during TG tests with the following trend: Fe–Ru0.4Na1 < Fe–Ru0.2Na1< Fe–Na1. Under air atmosphere, oxidation of surface C species to CO2 and transformation of Fe5C2 to Fe2O3 occurred simultaneously, which led to weight loss and weight increase respectively. Therefore, by combining the TG results with the mass ratio of Fe3O4 to Fe5C2 determined by the XRD results, the phase composition and carbon deposition of the spent Fe–RuxNa1 catalysts were quantitatively assessed. Considering its unique phase composition (Fe and Fe3C) of Fe–Ru0.6Na1, this catalyst was excluded from the discussion in this section. The data displayed in Fig. 5b showed that both the carbon deposition and the content of Fe5C2 on the catalysts decreased gradually with increasing Ru loading. These observations can also be explained by the enhanced removal of surface C* species, which is facilitated by the improved H2 activation capability of Ru. H2–TPD and CO2–TPD experiments were conducted on the reduced catalysts, aiming to investigate the difference in their reactant adsorption capacities (Fig. 6 ). For H2 adsorption behavior (Fig. 6a), the results showed that in the absence of Ru, H2 desorption mainly exhibited two peaks centered at 400–500 oC and 500–600 oC. As the Ru content increased, the intensity of both peaks significantly increased, and the desorption temperatures shifted towards higher temperature region. Specifically, the first desorption peak shifted from 410 oC to 450 oC, and the second one shifted from 550 oC to 650 oC. These results indicated that both the H2 adsorption capacity and adsorption strength of Fe-based catalysts were enhanced with increasing Ru content. This is consistent with the observed reaction performance, conforming that the introduction of Ru improved the hydrogenation capacity of the catalysts. The CO2–TPD results also presented significant differences, as shown in Fig. 6b. No CO2 desorption peak was detected for the Fe2O3 sample, whereas the introduction of promoters markedly enhanced the CO2 adsorption capacity. The Fe–Ru0.2Na1 exhibited the strongest CO2 adsorption capacity, with its desorption curve resembling a combination of the Fe–Ru0.2 and Fe–Na1 profiles, indicating the promotional effects of Ru and Na on CO2 adsorption and activation are retained in the catalyst with Ru–Na dual promoters. 3.4 Promotion mechanism discussion In a typical FTS process, there are three pathways to consume the C* species derived from CO dissociation: hydrogenation to hydrocarbon products, penetrating into the bulk Fe phase to form active carbides or depositing on the surface to form amorphous carbon or graphene [43,46,47]. Alkali metals such as Na are widely recognized as electronic promoters that enhance CO dissociation and C–C coupling. We proposed that in our catalyst series, Ru primarily functioned to improve hydrogenation activity, while Na promoted the enrichment of C* intermediates, based on the above observations. This dual functionality, however, presents a delicate balance: excessive hydrogenation facilitated by Ru may inhibit the carburization of Fe and result in a higher proportion of alkane products; whereas an overabundance of C* intermediates promoted by Na could accelerate surface carbon deposition, thereby hindering the further conversion of CO2. By optimizing the Ru/Na ratio, a synergistic effect can be achieved through the balanced regulation of surface C* and H* species, ultimately enhancing CO2 hydrogenation performance. To support our conclusion, we evaluated the series of Ru, Na co-modified catalysts for CO hydrogenation, inspired by Li et al.’s work [48]. Compared to CO2, CO undergoes easier dissociation, generating a higher concentration of surface C* species [48]. As a result, stronger hydrogenation capability is required to promptly remove the excess C* species. The catalytic performance of FTS over the Ru–Na co-modified catalysts shown in Fig. 7 and Table 2 agrees well with our former hypothesis. Similar to CO2 hydrogenation, Ru improved the FTS performance at lower content, but further inhibited the catalytic activity when reaching a certain amount. The difference lies in the fact that the optimal Ru content for CO hydrogenation is 0.6 %, significantly higher than that for CO2 hydrogenation (0.2 %). This is attributed to the higher concentration of surface C* species in CO hydrogenation. The formation of intermediates was monitored using in situ FTIR spectroscopy, as depicted in Fig. 8 . The spectra were collected at 0, 0.5, 1, 2 and 4 min after the introduction of the reactant gas (Fig. S4). The band located at 3016 cm-1 was assigned to CH4 [49,50]. The bands at 3080 and 2965 cm-1 were assigned to v(C–H) in =C–H and v(C–H) in CH2 and CH3, respectively [51,52]. The Fe–Ru0.2Na1 sample exhibited the most intense peaks corresponding to CH4 and -CHx intermediates, indicating its highest activity in the tested series. In Fig. 8b, the bands located at 2180 and 2112 cm-1 were assigned to gaseous CO. Upon promoter addition, the peak intensities of these two peaks decreased. Particularly, the Fe-Ru0.2Na1 exhibited the lowest intensity of gaseous CO. And simultaneously, the peaks located at 2376 and 2316 cm-1 appeared, attributable to gaseous CO2. These observations were consistent with the FTS performance. We acquired in situ Raman patterns to monitor the formation of carbon deposits. According to the literature, the D band and G band located at 1350 and 1580 cm-1 respectively, are characteristic peaks of carbon species [53–55]. As shown in Fig. 9 , after introducing H2 and CO as reactants, the Raman spectra were collected every 10 min. Distinct carbon peaks were observed at 60 min for Fe2O3, 80 min for Fe–Ru0.2, 10 min for Fe–Na1, and 20 min for Fe–Ru0.2Na1. The temporal evaluation showed that the formation rate of carbon deposits was significantly influenced by the addition of promoters. The introduction of Ru mitigated the promoting effect of Na on carbon deposition, consistent with our hypothesis. 4 Conclusion This study reported the introduction of Ru–Na dual promoters in Fe–based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation, revealing a synergistic effect between these two elements. Optimal Ru/Na ratios were found to substantially enhance CO₂ conversion efficiency, while reducing CO selectivity and suppressing lower alkanes formation. Multiple characterizations (including TPR, TPD, in situ IR, Raman etc.) demonstrated that the addition of Ru promoter upon Na modification enabled an effective removal of surface C* through facilitated formation of CHx intermediates and subsequent C–C coupling, thereby (1) enhancing CO2 conversion, (2) shifting product distribution toward olefins and long-chain hydrocarbons (3) suppressing carbon deposition. However, beyond the optimal ratio threshold would inhibit Fe carburization and diminished FTS activity, while concurrently enhancing alkanes formation capability. Given that CO exhibits higher reactivity than CO2, switching the reactant to CO highlighted the importance of balanced hydrogenation and CO dissociation capabilities. Consequently, we proposed that modulating surface C* and H* concentrations govern phase composition and carbon deposition, which is the key to achieving high FTS ability, controllable selectivity and long-term durability. The work establishes a general design principle for manipulating surface intermediate dynamics through complementary promoter combinations, offering tangible guidance for developing advanced CO/CO₂ hydrogenation catalysts with customizable performance characteristics. coredata.dc:description: The Fe-based catalysts are extensively employed for CO2 conversion into lower olefins, fuels and value-added chemicals. Addition of promoters is an efficient strategy to improve activity and manipulate product distribution. Herein, the effect of Ru-Na dual promoters on Fe-based catalysts were systematically investigated. Optimal Ru/Na ratios were found to substantially enhance CO₂ conversion efficiency, while reducing CO selectivity and suppressing lower alkanes formation. Multiple characterizations (TPD, XRD, XPS) were applied to illustrate the influence of the promoters on physiochemical properties of catalysts. Further in situ FTIR and Raman experiments, combined with FTS performance evaluation, revealed the synergistic and balanced effect between the two promoters. This work establishes a general design principle for achieving promoted performance by manipulating surface intermediates concentration, offering valuable guidance for developing advanced CO₂ hydrogenation catalysts.
